At 18:25 08/11/2005, you wrote:
>On 11/8/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> > >It's just an idea.  I'm not sure if it has any benefits over the
> > >existing system or not.  Nor do I have a clear idea of how it might be
> > >implemented.  But maybe there is merit to the idea.  Anybody have any
> > >thoughts or comments?
> >
> > I'm still contemplating my next move, but it sounds like we're coming
> > at the same limitations with different approaches?
>
>Perhaps.  Recognize speciation for what it was: an attempt to protect
>genetic diversity.

I wasn't supposing otherwise.  In fact, I would go further an say I 
was only treating it as a way of increasing search efficiency.  The 
theory is that this happens by increasing diversity, but I wouldn't 
call that proven...

>   Explore the possibility that speciation, while
>being *A* way to accomplish that goal, may not be the ONLY way, and it
>may not even be the BEST way.  Humans are only ONE species.  Yet we
>have a great deal of genetic diversity.   There must be a way, within
>the species itself, of accomplishing that goal.
>
>The more I think about it, the more I think that the hard-edged
>demarcation of boundaries is not the best way to go.

This was the idea behind my "heap selection" but I still didn't come 
up with a formulation of that that really gelled.

>   The existence of
>'variable speciation threshold' is evidence that such is the case.
>
>If you randomly select from a population, the results of your sample
>set should be proportional to the proportions of the population.  We
>don't want that.  We want to maintain the genetic diversity.  But, of
>course, we want to manage our resource allocation based on productive
>search areas.  So an elegant and flexible method is needed that lets
>us control where in this 'diverse' sea of genomes we focus.
>
>What is an elegant (even if it is computationally intense) solution
>besides speciation?
>
>Well, speciation, done right, is basically 'clustering'.

An alternative view is that each species represents a 
semi-independent search.  e.g. suppose I have two machines and each 
day I copy the same population onto each, seed their random numbers 
differently, and then leave them running all day.  In the evening I 
have two examples of different ways that the same random search could 
proceed.  I probably cannot merge them, because innovation numbers 
have not be synchronized between them.  But I can take the best of 
the two and discard the whole of the other.  This, to my mind, is the 
most primitive use of "species"...

Those two populations do represent different samples of the search 
space, but they don't really represent clusters, it is more that each 
one represents a different path across the search space (although 
only the end-point still exists when I look at them in the 
evening).  If you imagine the result of me repeating this over a lot 
of days, then the total path explored is branched, with a split 
appearing each morning and the less-successful of the two branches 
becoming a dead-end each evening.

My idea for the more advanced use of species (or "species", since 
they are not necessarily like real ones) is like this, except with 
the hope of not just discarding the less successful ones, but also 
having the chance to merge anything unique they have discovered back 
into the main-stream.

I think there is more to that than clustering, but it depends a lot 
on your problem space.  If you search space is essentially just a 
space, then maintaining diversity is probably the best you can do, 
e.g. the space doesn't have internal structure and there is no reason 
to believe that merging unique features of two partial solutions 
would lead to any better solution (in the same way that merging 
locations in London with ones in Manchester doesn't find points of 
high population density).  Most problems are richer than that, 
however.  Their solution spaces have internal structure 
(partial-independence of the parts of the solution) so that merging 
parts of different solutions can lead to good results.  e.g. in TTT 
you might merge an individual who can play for winning lines with one 
who can block losing lines, and end up with a better player overall...

>   Done right,
>clustering doesn't have a fixed threshold.  Nor does it have a fixed
>cluster count.  Clusters are where clusters are.  Just find them.  So
>the work to maintain a fixed number of species probably isn't a good
>idea.  But you can't have every individual in their own species,
>right?  Only because of how a species is used to constrain
>reproduction.  If reproduction were constrained not by cluster but by
>individual pairings of compatible individuals, then the whole concept
>of a species would not be necessary.  It would, however, be useful for
>controlling resource allocation, so an alternative / replacement would
>be needed.

All this is true, but I think you are making the implicit assumption 
that the distance metric used to determine the distance between 
individuals reflects something real about the solution 
space.  Unfortunately this is not the case, one small area of space 
might contain several solutions that we would want to call different, 
whereas another area might be huge but contain only solutions that we 
would want to call the same...

Unfortunately any distance metric is going to be at best an estimate 
of how different two individuals are algorithmically.

So what I'm saying is if you spread the individuals too evenly 
according to the distance metric, you might doom 99% of them to be in 
unproductive areas, just because the productive areas are relatively small...

>Say you have 1000 individuals in the population.  Pair them up, and
>you have 500 pairs.  Each pair could be combined in multiple ways.  So
>each pairing could produce 2-5 (or more) offspring.  Let's say they
>all produce 5 offspring.  You could then re-pair each individual with
>a different individual.  Repeat however often you like.  Add to that
>elitism, selecting the most fit individuals from each region of the
>search space.  Add to that random weight mutations.  And random
>topology mutations.
>
>Let's say that your 1000 individuals become, for the sake of argument,
>10,000 individuals.  Now, you don't want to test them all.  So,
>instead, you sample the 1000 of them that best represent the whole
>search space covered by that 10,000, with a little bias for areas of
>the search space where the fitness is higher.

You lost me.  There can't be any point in generating individuals that 
are not tested?  I can understand if you wanted to test some of them 
more heavily than others, but surely an individual that is created 
and deleted without ever being tested has effectively never existed?

         Ian

>The purist that tries to squeeze out every last bit of performance
>from the genome portion of the evolution would probably call that a
>waste of computational resources.  But for a really large and complex
>search space, I propose that this will make for a much more efficient
>search that is less likely to get stuck in a local optima.  Thus,
>reducing the amount of fitness evaluations (the really expensive part
>of any non-trivial domain), you win in the end.
>
>But the only way to know for sure is to try it out and see what the
>results are.  That means figuring out the right way to do that
>'sampling'.  Anybody have any suggestions on how best do do that
>representative sampling of the search space covered by the 10,000
>individuals?
>
>-- John
